details.title: A probabilistic approach to evaluate the reliability of piezoelectric micro-actuators

p: Zhimin He received his B. Eng. (1984) and M. Eng. (1990) in Solid Mechanics and Mechanical Engineering from Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST), and Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (BUAA), China respectively. From 1990–1996 he worked at Electric Power Construction Research Institute (EPCRI), China on reliability of power piping systems and pressure vessels, as an engineer and R&D manager. He received his second M. Eng. (1997) from National University of Singapore. Following with his M. Eng. study, he has been working at Data Storage Institute, a national institute under the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A∗STAR) of the Republic of Singapore, as a Senior Research Engineer. His research interests include dynamics and reliability of magnetic recording servo mechanical systems and mechatronics.

Han Tong Loh obtained his Bachelor and Master of Engineering from the University of Adelaide and the National University of Singapore, respectively. He continued his education at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Michigan where he received his M.S. and Ph.D. Han Tong Loh is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the National University of Singapore (NUS). He is the Deputy Head (Research) of the Department. He is also a Fellow of the Singapore-MIT Alliance, which is an innovative engineering education and research collaboration between MIT, NUS and the Nanyang Technological University, to promote global education and research in engineering. Dr Loh's research interests are in the areas of data mining, rapid prototyping, robust design and computer aided design.

Eng Hong Ong received his B.Eng (Hons) from the National University of Singapore (NUS) in 1991, he then went on to do a direct Ph.D. with the same university on nonlinear and chaotic dynamics. He is currently a research scientist with Data Storage Institute, a national institute under the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A∗STAR) of the Republic of Singapore. His areas of research include finite element analysis, multibody dynamics and mechatronics. He is also an adjunct fellow of NUS and he conducts two courses for the program of Master of Science in Mechatronics: 1) Mechanical Components and Systems, and 2) Kinematics and Dynamics of Mechanisms.

details.abstract: In this paper, a probabilistic design approach is presented to evaluate the reliability of piezoelectric micro actuators. Based on the relationship between the lifetime, and degradation mechanism of piezoelectric actuators, and the electric field strength, the concept of "electric strength" is proposed to indicate the electric field strength of the piezoelectric actuators at a specified lifetime. The lifetime (number of cycles to failure) of the piezoelectric actuator, electric strength, and electric load are considered as the random variables; and their probability distributions are discussed. The interference model of electric load, and electric strength is introduced to the reliability design of piezoelectric micro actuators. By this approach, the relationship between the reliability, and the lifetime of the piezoelectric actuator can be given. A case study of the disk drive head positioning system demonstrates the application of the approach.

references.title: Materials issues in design and performance of piezoelectric actuators: an overview

context.text: THE APPLICATION of piezoelectric actuators has increased remarkably in many fields which utilize vibrations around the resonance frequency, such as in ultrasonic motors, precision positioners, and adaptive mechanical dampers [1]–[4].

references.text: K. Uchino, "Materials issues in design and performance of piezoelectric actuators: an overview", Acta Mater, vol. 46, no. 11, pp. 3745-3753, 1998.

references.title: Piezoelectric actuators in micropositioning

context.text: THE APPLICATION of piezoelectric actuators has increased remarkably in many fields which utilize vibrations around the resonance frequency, such as in ultrasonic motors, precision positioners, and adaptive mechanical dampers [1]–[2][4].

links.abstract: Micromachines can be built only with the aid of other machines that have micropositioning abilities. Fast and precise positioning devices are needed to increase reliability and speed in the production of the miniaturized devices. Intensive research effort has been devoted to developing new technologies for actuators and sensors. A wide range of technologies is now available and it is not possible to say that one is the best: rather there is a best choice for each application. Piezoelectric actua...

references.text: M. Pozzi, T. King, "Piezoelectric actuators in micropositioning", Eng. Sci. Educ. J., pp. 31-36, Feb. 2001.

links.abstract: This paper proposes an optimization based control scheme for a dual-stage hard disk drive servo system to maximize the tracking accuracy given the actuator bandwidth limitations without knowing the mechanical disturbance model. We proposed to add an outer loop, selected based on optimization of the Youla parameters, to the usual dual-stage controller for tracking accuracy improvement. The Youla parameters are bounded based on specifications of minimum bandwidth, phase margin, and gain margin, an...

references.text: G. X. Guo, Q. Hao, T. S. Low, "A dual-stage control design for high track per inch hard disk drives", IEEE Trans. Magn., vol. 37, no. 2, pp. 860-865, 2001.

references.title: Life prediction method for Piggyback PZT actuator

context.text: In general, these researches can be categorized as life cycle of the multi-layer ceramic actuator [5], [6], actuator environmental stability [7], and fracture/crack growth of piezoelectric ceramics [8]–[11].

According to previous research [5]–[11], the performance & lifetime of piezoelectric actuators are sensitive to the operation environment, and external mechanical & electric loads; experimental data shows the scatter & diversity of the material properties, and the actuator performance.
A push-pull multi-layer piggyback piezoelectric actuator, and a dual stage system of hard disk drive [5].

[18], electromagnetic [19], and piezoelectric micro actuators [3]–[5], [15], [20].
From their publication [5], we calculated the experimental data of lifetime, and driving voltage at 25°C as listed in Table I.

links.abstract: The experimental lifetime predictive equation for a piggyback PZT actuator was derived. A piggyback actuator is a fine actuator of a dual-stage servo system that is essential to increase the recording density of hard disk drives (HDD's). The obtained equation agrees with Arrhenius' equation. The lifetime of our developed actuator was estimated to be longer than 5 years under heavy use conditions. This lifetime prediction method is useful for designing piggyback PZT actuators for high-performance...

references.text: S. Nakamura, "Life prediction method for Piggyback PZT actuator", IEEE Trans. Magn., vol. 37, no. 2, pp. 940-943, March 2001.

references.title: Lifetime and degradation mechanism of multilayer ceramic actuator

context.text: In general, these researches can be categorized as life cycle of the multi-layer ceramic actuator [5], [6], actuator environmental stability [7], and fracture/crack growth of piezoelectric ceramics [8]–[11].

According to previous research [5]–[6][11], the performance & lifetime of piezoelectric actuators are sensitive to the operation environment, and external mechanical & electric loads; experimental data shows the scatter & diversity of the material properties, and the actuator performance.
The relationship between the lifetime, and the electric field strength of multi-layer piezoelectric is revealed by Thongueng [6],.

references.text: J. Thongrueng, "Lifetime and degradation mechanism of multilayer ceramic actuator", Jpn. J Appl. Phys., vol. 37, pp. 5306-5310, 1998.

references.title: Electromechanical fatigue behavior of graphite/epoxy laminate embedded with piezoelectric actuator

context.text: In general, these researches can be categorized as life cycle of the multi-layer ceramic actuator [5], [6], actuator environmental stability [7], and fracture/crack growth of piezoelectric ceramics [8]–[11].

Probabilistic approach-based reliability analysis has been widely practiced in the fatigue design, and life cycles estimation of mechanical components & structures due to the scatter of material properties, and environment uncertainties [8], [9].

According to previous research [5]–[8][11], the performance & lifetime of piezoelectric actuators are sensitive to the operation environment, and external mechanical & electric loads; experimental data shows the scatter & diversity of the material properties, and the actuator performance.

references.text: S. Mall, T. L. Hsu, "Electromechanical fatigue behavior of graphite/epoxy laminate embedded with piezoelectric actuator", Smart Materials and Structures, vol. 9, no. 1, pp. 78-84, 2000.

references.title: Mechanical Reliability, Design

context.text: For the reliability practice in conventional fatigue design & life estimation, \$P{\hbox {-}}S{\hbox {-}}N\$ curve, i.e., the relationship among the Probability, Stress level, and the Number of cycles to failure is used to estimate the fatigue life at a certain reliability level [12]–[14].
The well-known stress-strength interference model for mechanical reliability [12] is introduced here for the reliability evaluation of piezoelectric actuators.

references.text: A. D. S. Carter, Mechanical Reliability Design, 1997, Macmillan Press Ltd.

references.title: Probability density function of fatigue strength

context.text: For the reliability practice in conventional fatigue design & life estimation, \$P{\hbox {-}}S{\hbox {-}}N\$ curve, i.e., the relationship among the Probability, Stress level, and the Number of cycles to failure is used to estimate the fatigue life at a certain reliability level [12]–[13][14].
In fatigue reliability, it has been proved that in a \$P{\hbox {-}}S{\hbox {-}}N\$ curve, the failure probability of the fatigue life equals that of the fatigue strength [13].

references.text: H. Fu, Z. T. Gao, "Probability density function of fatigue strength", Proc. Int. Conf. Structural Saf. Reliab., pp. 765-774, 1985.

references.title: Random Fatigue: From Data to Theory

context.text: For the reliability practice in conventional fatigue design & life estimation, \$P{\hbox {-}}S{\hbox {-}}N\$ curve, i.e., the relationship among the Probability, Stress level, and the Number of cycles to failure is used to estimate the fatigue life at a certain reliability level [12]–[14].
For the general case, the load-time process can be taken as stationary stochastic process [14].

references.text: K. Sobczyk, B. F. Spencer Jr., Random Fatigue: From Data to Theory, 1992, Academic Press, Inc.

They are, electrostatic [16]–
[18], electromagnetic [19], and piezoelectric micro actuators [3]–[5], [15], [20].

links.abstract: This paper presents a microfabricated actuator designed for high precision servo-positioning in a magnetic hard disk drive. The device is actuated using electrostatic force generated with parallel-plate capacitive electrodes. The displacement of these electrodes is measured using a dedicated capacitive sensing interface, allowing closed-loop control to be used to extend the servo bandwidth. Using the sensing electronics and a simple phase-lead compensator, a prototype device was used to actuate ...

references.text: D. A. Horsley, N. Wongkomet, R. Horowitz, A. P. Pisano, "Precision positioning using a microfabricated electrostatic actuator", IEEE Trans. Magn., vol. 35, no. 2, pp. 993-999, 1999.

references.title: Electrostatic microactuator and design considerations for HDD applications

context.text:
They are, electrostatic [16]–[17]
[18], electromagnetic [19], and piezoelectric micro actuators [3]–[5], [15], [20].

links.abstract: A flexure-based rotary electrostatic microactuator is described. This microactuator is for application in a high track-density hard disk drive (HDD). It is fabricated using a high aspect-ratio stencil electroplating process. This paper emphasizes the practical system-level issues that affect the device design. The micro-actuator is demonstrated in a 3.5" form-factor HDD. With a servo bandwidth of 5 kHz, a one-track seek can be completed in under 0.2 ms. This batch-fabricated electro-static micro...

references.text: L. S. Fan, T. Hirano, J. Hong, P. R. Webb, W. H. Juan, W. Y. Lee, S. Chan, T. Semba, W. Imaino, "Electrostatic microactuator and design considerations for HDD applications", IEEE Trans. Magn., vol. 35, no. 2, pp. 1000-1005, 1999.

references.title: A flexural Piggyback milli-actuator for over 100

context.text:
They are, electrostatic [16]–
[18], electromagnetic [19], and piezoelectric micro actuators [3]–[5], [15], [20].

links.abstract: A new milli-scale piggyback actuator for magnetic disk drives with a high track density was developed. The movable part of this actuator is comprised of a head suspension assembly supported by a 'flexural' cross-shaped spring, driven in the rotary direction by electromagnetic force. The advantages are that the actuator moves over a long distance with small power and can be easily manufactured. Our dual-stage actuator system using the flexural milli-actuator can realize 25 kTPI.

references.text: S. Koganezawa, K. Takaishi, Y. Mizoshita, Y. Uematsu, T. Yamada, S. Hasegawa, T. Ueno, " A flexural Piggyback milli-actuator for over 100 \${rm Gbit/in}^{2}\$ density magnetic recording ", IEEE Trans. Magn., vol. 32, no. 5, pp. 3908-3910, 1996.

links.abstract: This paper documents results related to design optimization, fabrication process refinement, and micron-level static/dynamic testing of silicon micromachined microgimbals that have applications in super-compact computer disk drives as well as many other engineering applications of microstructures and microactuators requiring significant out-of-plane motions. The objective of the optimization effort is to increase the in-plane to out-of-plane stiffness ratio in order to maximize compliance and se...

references.text: V. Temesvary, S. Wu, W. H. Hsieh, Y. C. Tai, D. K. Miu, "Design fabrication and testing of silicon microgimbals for super-compact rigid disk drives", J. Microelectromech. Syst., vol. 4, no. 1, pp. 18-27, Mar. 1995.

The input voltage signals of a piezoelectric micro actuator (a type of \$\Phi\$ shape piezoelectric micro actuator [20]) to allow the read/write head to follow a particular track are recorded while the actuator assembly is experiencing the external disturbances.

links.abstract: A suspension-based piezoelectric microactuator has been developed for dual-stage servo systems in hard disk drives. The suspension is designed to meet the requirements of high recording density, high shock resistance, high productivity, and a load/unload structure. This paper describes the structure of the actuator and its mechanical characteristics.

references.text: M. Tokuyama, T. Shimizu, H. Masuda, S. Nakamura, M. Hanya, O. Iriuchijima, J. Soga, " Development of a \$Phi\$ -shaped actuated suspension for 100-kTPI hard disk drives ", IEEE Trans. Magn., vol. 37, no. 4, pp. 1884-1886, 2001.
